paragraphs.text: Argentina: Growth at what price?
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: Argentina has chosen a certain path for development that is diametrically opposed to what is required to mitigate the problems of climate change
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: as Argentinean representatives attend the Climate Change Summit in Peru
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: it's worth looking at its poor environmental record
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Average temperature in the southern region of Patagonia has increased one degree Celsius in the last 50 years
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: provoking the retreat of the largest glaciers in the region
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: During the same period, rains increased by 10 percent in the east
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: severe flooding in northeastern Argentina has been linked to the change in the use of the land and the deterioration of local ecosystems
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In addition
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the country has suffered from increased sea levels, reduction in fresh water bodies, desertification, severe storms and tornadoes
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Argentina has a rate of deforestation of 0.8 percent per year - twice that of the Amazon region, or about 26 hectares per hour
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Despite the Forest Act coming into force in February 2009
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: over one million hectares of native woods were destroyed between 2009 and 2012
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: The Forest Act budget for 2015 has been set at just 300 million pesos ($27m) instead of the 3.1 billion pesos ($364m)
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: as
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: requested by environmental activists
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: The national government has consistently failed to properly fund the implementation of the Forest Act, making it completely ineffective
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Local governments continue to authorise the deforestation of protected woods at the request of local landowners, generating a serious environmental impact, the displacement of indigenous and peasant populations and the persecution of environmental activists
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: While high temperatures continue to push the consumption of electricity to record levels
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: demand for electricity is set to grow at an average of 5.5 percent per year
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Argentina is far from achieving its target of 8 percent renewable energy generation by 2016
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In 2013, investment for smaller scale hydro clean energy fell 70 percent from $2.7bn to just $153m
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: At the end of 2012, only 1.4 percent of all electricity produced was from renewable resources
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Meanwhile in 2013, the Supreme Court lifted an embargo on Chevron's assets in Argentina
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: so
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it could enter into an agreement to exploit the shale gas site at Vaca Muerta, in the province of Neuquen
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Chevron, which has been condemned by courts in Ecuador for environmental damage, has pledged $1.5bn to develop it
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Each of the 1,500 planned fracking wells will use up to 12 million litres of water
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The Mapuche indigenous communities living nearby oppose the development
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: as
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it will increase contamination of their subterranean water supply
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Argentina is the third largest producer of soy after the US and Brazil, exporting practically all of its production to Europe and China and providing much needed revenue for the government at a time when it faces increased demands to pay its external debts
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: The use of soy for biofuels has promoted deforestation
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: its expansion has generated enormous greenhouse gas emissions due to the loss of forest mass and the changes in the use of the land
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Thanks to a reduction in the taxation of biofuel exports and other tax incentives, the production of biodiesel reached a historical record in September 2014, totalling nearly 1.9m tonnes in the first nine months of 2014
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: In the last few years, the area for maize cultivation for biofuel has increased
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Greenpeace points out that corn-based bioethanol has an extremely poor energetic balance
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: while civil society organisations question the use of agricultural land to produce grains to feed machines rather than people
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Still
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: there are signs of hope
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: On December 3, the Argentinean Senate approved tax incentives for the generation of electricity from renewable energy sources
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The Chamber of Deputies is likely to make it law next year
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But in light of Argentina's environmental record, there is clearly a lot of work yet to be done and many more laws and policies to be implemented
paragraphs.label: assumption
